readingAnalyses.title: Yi Kangnyŏn: Open Letter to Itō Hirobumi
readingAnalyses.author: Yi Kangnyŏn (이강년, 1858-1908)
readingAnalyses.summary: A Righteous Army commander writes directly to Japan's Resident-General. Yi Kangnyŏn's letter is a point-by-point indictment of Japanese imperialism: invasion, assassination of Queen Min, exploitation of finances, violation of the Treaty of Shimonoseki. The tone is furious and uncompromising, backed by the threat of armed resistance from guerrilla forces across the Korean countryside.

keyQuotes.quote: Have we asked to become a colony of your country, a nation devoid of morality?
You have violated international commitments vis-a-vis other nations. You have deceived your own sovereign. In our country, you have become an unforgivable enemy.

thematicExamples: Armed resistance as first response to colonialism
Invocation of international law and treaty obligations

readingAnalyses.title: The Patriotic Enlightenment Movement
readingAnalyses.author: Korean Association for Self-Strengthening (Taehan Chaganghoe)
readingAnalyses.summary: After 1905, private associations emerged promoting education and economic development as paths to eventual independence. The Korean Association for Self-Strengthening (est. March 1906), led by Yun Ch'iho with Chang Chiyŏn and Yun Hyojŏng, aimed to build Korea into a modern nation strong enough to resist Japan. A fundamentally different strategy from armed resistance: national capacity-building rather than military confrontation.

keyQuotes.quote: The enlightenment movement aimed at building up Korea as a modern advanced nation with a strong economic base in order to push Japan out eventually.

thematicExamples: Self-strengthening as alternative to armed resistance

readingAnalyses.title: Son Pyŏnghŭi and Others: Declaration of Independence
readingAnalyses.author: Drafted by Ch'oe Namsŏn; signed by 33 representatives
readingAnalyses.summary: The centerpiece document. Drafted by the 29-year-old publisher Ch'oe Namsŏn, read aloud on March 1, 1919, this declaration sparked massive nationwide protests. The tone is remarkably dignified and non-violent: it frames Korean independence as universal justice, explicitly refuses to demonize Japan, and commits to moral suasion over violence. The 33 signers (15 Ch'ŏndogyo, 16 Christian, 2 Buddhist) called the police after reading it and waited to be arrested.

keyQuotes.quote: We hereby declare that Korea is an independent state and that Koreans are a self-governing people.
Our task today is to build up our own strength, not to destroy others.
Our action today represents the demand of our people for justice, humanity, survival, and dignity.

thematicExamples: Wilsonian moment: hopes that self-determination would apply to colonies
Religion as organizational backbone (Japan controlled all secular institutions)

readingAnalyses.title: Provisional Constitution of the Korean Government in Exile
readingAnalyses.author: Korean Provisional Government
readingAnalyses.summary: Within weeks of March First, Korean activists established a provisional government in Shanghai's French Concession. Its constitution is strikingly modern: democratic republic, no class distinctions, equality of men and women. Yi Tongnyŏng headed the legislature; Syngman Rhee the executive. This government became the rallying point for Korean independence until 1945.

readingAnalyses.title: Declaration of War on Japan (9 December 1941)
readingAnalyses.author: Korean Provisional Government
readingAnalyses.summary: Two days after Pearl Harbor, the Korean Provisional Government declared war on Japan, aligning with the Allied powers. The declaration voids the 1910 annexation treaty and all unequal treaties, invokes the Atlantic Charter's promise of self-government, and commits to fighting to final victory. An assertion of sovereignty by a government that no major power recognized.

overallSynthesis:
These six documents trace a 46-year evolution in Korean resistance strategy: armed guerrilla warfare (Yi Kangnyŏn, 1895-1908), enlightenment-era self-strengthening (1906), moral appeal to universal justice (March First, 1919), exile government-building (Shanghai, 1919), and finally military alliance (1941).

Each strategy failed on its own terms. The Righteous Armies were outgunned. Self-strengthening was overtaken by annexation. The March First moral appeal fell on deaf ears at Versailles. The Provisional Government spent 26 years without diplomatic recognition. Yet the fire of Korean nationalism was kept alive throughout 35 years of colonial rule.

The contrast with Japanese nationalism (Plate 17) is sharp. Where Tokutomi Sohō embraced Social Darwinist competition, Korean nationalists appealed to international law and human dignity. Where Japan sought to dominate, Korea sought recognition. Japanese nationalism was about power; Korean nationalism was about justice.

The comparison with Chinese nationalism (Plate 19) is instructive. Both emerged from humiliation and resistance. But Korean nationalism crystallized under direct colonial occupation, creating a sharper victim identity. Chinese nationalism developed in a semi-colonial context with more room for internal debate.
executiveSummary:
Six documents spanning 1895-1941 trace the arc of Korean resistance to Japanese imperialism. Yi Kangnyŏn's Open Letter to Itō Hirobumi (pp. 294-295) is the voice of armed resistance from the Righteous Armies. The Patriotic Enlightenment Movement (pp. 295-296) represents the bet on education and economic self-strengthening. The Declaration of Independence (pp. 336-339), drafted by Ch'oe Namsŏn and signed by 33 representatives, is the centerpiece: a remarkably dignified, non-violent appeal to universal justice that sparked the March First Movement of 1919. The Provisional Constitution (p. 339) established a democratic exile government in Shanghai. The Declaration of War (pp. 350-351), issued two days after Pearl Harbor, aligned Korea with the Allied powers.

Three strategies, one goal: armed resistance, self-strengthening, moral appeal. All failed to achieve independence directly. Japan was too strong, the international community indifferent. Yet each built the scaffolding of Korean national identity that persists today.

keyQuestions.question: The reading contains three distinct strategies for Korean resistance: armed revolt (Righteous Armies), self-strengthening (enlightenment movement), and moral appeal (March First Declaration). Which was most effective, and why?
keyQuestions.basicAnswer: Each strategy failed to achieve independence directly. The Righteous Armies were outgunned, self-strengthening was overtaken by annexation, and the moral appeal was ignored at Versailles.
keyQuestions.midAnswer: None achieved independence, but March First succeeded as nation-building. It created national consciousness, martyrs, a founding myth, and an exile government. The movement's 'failure' produced the identity infrastructure that both Koreas still use.
keyQuestions.advancedAnswer: The question itself reveals a bias. 'Effectiveness' measured by independence is a power framework. The Declaration's authors explicitly rejected that framework: 'Our task today is to build up our own strength, not to destroy others.' They were playing a different game, one measured by moral clarity and national consciousness rather than military victory.

keyQuestions.question: How does Korean nationalism (Plate 18) differ from Japanese nationalism (Plate 17)?
keyQuestions.basicAnswer: Japanese nationalism was expansionist, based on power and Social Darwinism. Korean nationalism was defensive, based on victimhood and justice claims.
keyQuestions.midAnswer: They operate in different frameworks. Tokutomi Sohō's Japanese nationalism asks 'How do we dominate?' Korean nationalists ask 'How do we survive with dignity?' Japan cited the logic of the strong; Korea appealed to the conscience of the world.
keyQuestions.advancedAnswer: Korean nationalism was forged in the crucible of Japanese nationalism. Without Japanese imperialism, Korean national consciousness might have developed very differently. The Declaration's non-violent, morally-grounded approach was a strategic response to overwhelming military disadvantage: when you can't win by force, you compete on legitimacy.

connections.fromPrevious: Plate 17 examined the Japanese nationalism that justified colonizing Korea (Tokutomi Sohō's Social Darwinism). Now we see the Korean response: not counter-aggression, but moral appeal.
connections.toNext: Plate 19 examines Chinese nationalism through Lu Xun's 'True Story of Ah Q.' Both Korean and Chinese nationalisms emerged from humiliation, but in different contexts: direct colonial occupation vs. semi-colonial exploitation.
connections.broaderThemes: Colonialism creates nationalism among the colonized. But the content varies. Korean nationalism emphasized victimhood and moral claims. Chinese nationalism turned inward toward self-criticism. Japanese nationalism reached for power. Three responses to the same modern moment.

nextPreview.preview: Chinese nationalism emerged from the 'century of humiliation.' Lu Xun's 'True Story of Ah Q' offers a scathing critique of Chinese national character. Where the Korean Declaration looks outward (appealing to the world), Lu Xun looks inward (diagnosing China's own failures).
readings: The True Story of Ah Q (Lu Xun)

teachingNotes: Read the Declaration of Independence aloud in class. It is eloquent and moving.
The Open Letter to Itō is NOT by An Jung-geun (a common confusion). It's by Yi Kangnyŏn, a Righteous Army commander.
Key comparison: 33 signers called the police on themselves and waited to be arrested. Contrast this with armed resistance.
Religious composition of the 33 signers (15 Ch'ŏndogyo, 16 Christian, 2 Buddhist) is analytically important: religion was the only organizational space Japan didn't fully control.
The Declaration's refusal to blame Japan ('we must first blame ourselves') is strategically sophisticated, not naïve.

authorBios.name: Yi Kangnyŏn
authorBios.bio: Confucian scholar from Mungyŏng who first raised volunteer forces in 1895 after the assassination of Queen Min. Became a general in the Thirteen Provinces Alliance. Captured and executed at Sŏdaemun Prison in 1908.

authorBios.name: Yun Ch'iho
authorBios.bio: Western-educated intellectual (Vanderbilt, Emory) who led the Independence Club and Korean Association for Self-Strengthening. Later collaborated with Japan, earning the label ch'inilp'a.

authorBios.name: Chang Chiyŏn
authorBios.bio: Editor of the Hwangsŏng sinmun. Famous for his 1905 editorial 'I Wail Bitterly Today' denouncing the Eulsa Treaty. Arrested for the editorial; became a symbol of press resistance.

authorBios.name: Son Pyŏnghŭi
authorBios.bio: Third leader of the Tonghak movement, who reorganized it as Ch'ŏndogyo in 1905. First signer of the Declaration of Independence. Read it at Taehwagwan Restaurant, then phoned the police. Died after falling ill in prison.

authorBios.name: Ch'oe Namsŏn
authorBios.bio: Founded Korea's first modern magazine (Sonyŏn) at age 18. Drafted the Declaration of Independence at age 29. Did not sign it himself. Later imprisoned, then collaborated with Japan during wartime.

authorBios.name: Han Yongun
authorBios.bio: Buddhist reformer, one of the 33 signers, drafted the Three Open Pledges. Published 'Nim ŭi ch'immuk' (Your Silence), a landmark of modern Korean literature. Built his house facing away from the Japanese Government-General building in defiance. Never collaborated.

authorBios.name: Syngman Rhee
authorBios.bio: First Korean to hold an American doctorate (Princeton, 1910). Elected president of the Korean Provisional Government in Shanghai. Later became first president of the Republic of Korea. Authoritarian ruler, overthrown by student revolution in 1960.
